title: Psoriasis
author: WebMD Editorial Contributors

content: Psoriasis is a common skin disorder that forms thick, red, bumpy patches covered with silvery scales. They can pop up anywhere, but most appear on the scalp, elbows, knees, and lower back.
Psoriasis can't be passed from person to person. It does sometimes happen in members of the same family.

It usually appears in early adulthood. For most people, it affects just a few areas. In severe cases, it can cover large parts of the body. The rashes can heal and then come back throughout a person's life.

content_blocks.text: Psoriasis is a common skin disorder that forms thick, red, bumpy patches covered with silvery scales. They can pop up anywhere, but most appear on the scalp, elbows, knees, and lower back.
Psoriasis can't be passed from person to person. It does sometimes happen in members of the same family.

It usually appears in early adulthood. For most people, it affects just a few areas. In severe cases, it can cover large parts of the body. The rashes can heal and then come back throughout a person's life.

sections.heading: Symptoms
content: Psoriasis starts as small, red bumps, which grow bigger and form scales. The skin appears thick but may bleed easily if you pick or rub off the scales.
Rashes may itch and skin may become cracked and painful. Nails may form pits, thicken, crack, and become loose.

content_blocks.text: Psoriasis starts as small, red bumps, which grow bigger and form scales. The skin appears thick but may bleed easily if you pick or rub off the scales.
Rashes may itch and skin may become cracked and painful. Nails may form pits, thicken, crack, and become loose.

sections.heading: How Do I Know if I Have Psoriasis?
content: If you have a rash that isn’t healing, see your doctor.

content_blocks.text: If you have a rash that isn’t healing, see your doctor.

sections.heading: Causes
content: No one knows the exact cause of psoriasis , but experts believe that it’s a combination of things. Something wrong with the immune system causes inflammation, triggering new skin cells to form too quickly. Normally, skin cells are replaced every 10 to 30 days. With psoriasis, new cells grow every 3 to 4 days. The buildup of old cells being replaced by new ones creates those silver scales.
Some things that can trigger outbreaks are:
Psoriasis isn’t contagious. You can’t catch it from someone else.
bullets: Cuts, scrapes, or surgery
Emotional stress
Strep infections

Something wrong with the immune system causes inflammation, triggering new skin cells to form too quickly. Normally, skin cells are replaced every 10 to 30 days. With psoriasis, new cells grow every 3 to 4 days. The buildup of old cells being replaced by new ones creates those silver scales.
Some things that can trigger outbreaks are:
associated_bullets: Cuts, scrapes, or surgery
Emotional stress
Strep infections

content_blocks.text: Psoriasis isn’t contagious. You can’t catch it from someone else.

sections.heading: Risk Factors
content: You’re more likely to get psoriasis if it runs in your family. Certain genes make it more likely.
Psoriasis usually starts in adults, but children can get it, too. It’s equally common in men and women.

content_blocks.text: You’re more likely to get psoriasis if it runs in your family. Certain genes make it more likely.
Psoriasis usually starts in adults, but children can get it, too. It’s equally common in men and women.

sections.heading: Treatment
content: Luckily, there are many treatments. Some slow the growth of new skin cells, and others relieve itching and dry skin. Your doctor will select a treatment plan that is right for you based on the size of your rash, where it is on your body, your age, your overall health, and other things. Common treatments include:
Treatments for moderate to severe cases of psoriasis include:
bullets: Steroid creams
Non-steroid creams such as roflumilast (Zoryve) , tacrolimus (Protopic), and tapinarof (Vtama)
Moisturizers for dry skin
Coal tar (a common treatment for scalp psoriasis; available in lotions, creams, foams, shampoos, and bath solutions)
Vitamin D cream (a strong kind ordered by your doctor; vitamin D in foods and pills has no effect)
Retinoid creams

Biologic treatments. These work by blocking the body's immune system (which is overactive in psoriasis) to better control the systemic inflammation linked to psoriasis. Biologic medications include adalimumab ( Humira ), brodalumab ( Siliq ), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), guselkumab (Tremfya), infliximab (Remicade), ixekizumab (Taltz), risankizumab-rzaa (Skyrizi), secukinumab ( Cosentyx ), tildrakizumab (Ilumya), and ustekinumab (Stelara).
Light therapy. A doctor uses ultraviolet light to slow the growth of skin cells. PUVA is a treatment that combines a medicine called psoralen with a special form of ultraviolet light.

Enzyme Inhibitor. The medication apremilast (Otezla) is a new kind of drug for long-term inflammatory diseases like psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis . It's a pill that works by blocking a specific enzyme, which helps to slow other reactions that lead to inflammation. D eucravacitinib (Sotyktu) may also be prescribed as an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

Methotrexate. This drug can cause liver disease and lung problems, so it’s only for serious cases. Doctors closely watch patients. You may have to get lab work, a chest X-ray, and possibly a liver biopsy.

Cyclosporine. This drug, made to suppress the immune system, may be taken for serious cases that do not respond to other treatments. It can damage the kidneys and raise blood pressure , though, so your doctor will closely watch your health while you take it.

Retinoids. These pills, creams, foams, and gels are a class of drugs related to vitamin A . Retinoids can cause serious side effects, including birth defects, so they’re not recommended for women who are pregnant or planning to have children.

Aryl hydrocarbon receptor agonist. Tapinarof ( Vtama ) is a new steroid-free topical cream that is an aryl hydrocarbon receptor agonist, approved to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis in adults. Applied once a day, it can be used on sensitive areas of the body and is safe for long-term use.

content: Luckily, there are many treatments. Some slow the growth of new skin cells, and others relieve itching and dry skin. Your doctor will select a treatment plan that is right for you based on the size of your rash, where it is on your body, your age, your overall health, and other things. Common treatments include:
Treatments for moderate to severe cases of psoriasis include:
bullets: Steroid creams
Non-steroid creams such as roflumilast (Zoryve) , tacrolimus (Protopic), and tapinarof (Vtama)
Moisturizers for dry skin
Coal tar (a common treatment for scalp psoriasis; available in lotions, creams, foams, shampoos, and bath solutions)
Vitamin D cream (a strong kind ordered by your doctor; vitamin D in foods and pills has no effect)
Retinoid creams

Biologic treatments. These work by blocking the body's immune system (which is overactive in psoriasis) to better control the systemic inflammation linked to psoriasis. Biologic medications include adalimumab ( Humira ), brodalumab ( Siliq ), certolizumab (Cimzia), etanercept (Enbrel), guselkumab (Tremfya), infliximab (Remicade), ixekizumab (Taltz), risankizumab-rzaa (Skyrizi), secukinumab ( Cosentyx ), tildrakizumab (Ilumya), and ustekinumab (Stelara).
Light therapy. A doctor uses ultraviolet light to slow the growth of skin cells. PUVA is a treatment that combines a medicine called psoralen with a special form of ultraviolet light.

Enzyme Inhibitor. The medication apremilast (Otezla) is a new kind of drug for long-term inflammatory diseases like psoriasis and psoriatic arthritis . It's a pill that works by blocking a specific enzyme, which helps to slow other reactions that lead to inflammation. D eucravacitinib (Sotyktu) may also be prescribed as an oral tyrosine kinase inhibitor.

Methotrexate. This drug can cause liver disease and lung problems, so it’s only for serious cases. Doctors closely watch patients. You may have to get lab work, a chest X-ray, and possibly a liver biopsy.

Cyclosporine. This drug, made to suppress the immune system, may be taken for serious cases that do not respond to other treatments. It can damage the kidneys and raise blood pressure , though, so your doctor will closely watch your health while you take it.

Retinoids. These pills, creams, foams, and gels are a class of drugs related to vitamin A . Retinoids can cause serious side effects, including birth defects, so they’re not recommended for women who are pregnant or planning to have children.

Aryl hydrocarbon receptor agonist. Tapinarof ( Vtama ) is a new steroid-free topical cream that is an aryl hydrocarbon receptor agonist, approved to treat moderate to severe plaque psoriasis in adults. Applied once a day, it can be used on sensitive areas of the body and is safe for long-term use.

sections.heading: Is There a Cure?
content: There’s no cure, but treatment greatly reduces symptoms, even in serious cases. Recent studies have suggested that when you better control the inflammation of psoriasis, the risk of heart disease , stroke, metabolic syndrome, and other diseases linked to inflammation also decreases.

content_blocks.text: There’s no cure, but treatment greatly reduces symptoms, even in serious cases. Recent studies have suggested that when you better control the inflammation of psoriasis, the risk of heart disease , stroke, metabolic syndrome, and other diseases linked to inflammation also decreases.

sections.heading: Complications
content: Psoriasis makes you more likely to have:
Other conditions – including heart disease, obesity, and type 2 diabetes – are more common among people with psoriasis. But it’s not clear why.
bullets: Psoriatic arthritis , which affects joints such as the fingers, toes, wrists, hips, sacroiliac joint, knees, ankles, and lower back. Most people with psoriasis don’t get psoriatic arthritis, but 10% to 30% do.
Anxiety, depression, and low self-esteem can happen if it affects your quality of life and you’re self-conscious about the condition.

content_blocks.text: Psoriasis makes you more likely to have:
associated_bullets: Psoriatic arthritis , which affects joints such as the fingers, toes, wrists, hips, sacroiliac joint, knees, ankles, and lower back. Most people with psoriasis don’t get psoriatic arthritis, but 10% to 30% do.
Anxiety, depression, and low self-esteem can happen if it affects your quality of life and you’re self-conscious about the condition.

content_blocks.text: Other conditions – including heart disease, obesity, and type 2 diabetes – are more common among people with psoriasis. But it’s not clear why.

sections.heading: Home Remedies
content: Self-care for psoriasis focuses on taking good care of your skin, managing stress, avoiding other triggers, and keeping up with your treatment. There aren’t any supplements or herbal remedies proven to help.

content_blocks.text: Self-care for psoriasis focuses on taking good care of your skin, managing stress, avoiding other triggers, and keeping up with your treatment. There aren’t any supplements or herbal remedies proven to help.

content: Some key tips:
Don’t scratch your psoriasis. You can soothe your skin with a cold compress or an ice pack.
Moisturize. You may want to pick a fragrance-free moisturizer that’s made for sensitive skin.
Wear sunscreen. Sunburns can worsen your psoriasis.

Practice stress management. Stress can trigger a flare-up of psoriasis. Try exercise, meditation, and spending time with people you like. If you’re feeling down or anxious about your psoriasis, look into therapy and treatment for help.

meta_description: From WebMD, an overview of psoriasis, a skin condition that forms thick, red patches.
